nodes.text: Increasing sleep among the urban poor will causally affect economic outcomes (productivity, labor supply, cognition, well-being, and preferences)
Objective field measurement via actigraphy and a randomized controlled trial can reliably identify causal effects of sleep interventions on economic outcomes in a low-income urban setting
Baseline objective sleep in low-income adults in Chennai shows severe sleep deprivation and low sleep efficiency despite long time in bed
A bundled night-sleep intervention (devices + information + encouragement or devices + incentives) increases nighttime sleep mainly by increasing time in bed but does not raise sleep efficiency
An afternoon workplace nap treatment increases daytime sleep (office naps) and yields higher sleep quality during naps compared with night sleep at home
Pooled night-sleep interventions produced no detectable improvements in overall economic index, productivity, cognition, well-being, or preferences, and reduced labor supply modestly

Nap intervention produced positive effects on an overall summary index, with significant improvements in productivity, psychological well-being, and lab measures of cognition but decreased work time relative to working through the nap period
Baseline actigraphy: average night sleep ~5.5 hours, average time in bed ~8 hours, sleep efficiency ~70%, ~31 awakenings per night, replicated in broader Chennai survey
Night-sleep treatments increased night sleep by about 27 minutes/night on average, driven by ~38 additional minutes in bed, with no significant change in sleep efficiency
Increasing sleep in this setting has high opportunity cost because low sleep efficiency implies more time in bed required per minute of sleep (1 minute sleep requires ~1.4 minutes in bed)
Office naps increased daytime sleep by ~14 minutes/day (unconditional) with high compliance and higher nap sleep efficiency (~85%) than night sleep
Naps partially crowd out nighttime sleep modestly (~7â€“8 minutes) but increase 24-hour sleep less than night-sleep treatment; nap environment likely higher comfort

Conclusion: Marginal increases in nighttime sleep via increased time in bed do not generate the expected economic benefits in this urban poor setting, whereas short workplace naps produce measurable cognitive, productivity, and psychological benefits despite some labor-time costs

Interpretation and external validity caveats: low sleep efficiency may explain null night-sleep benefits; lab results from extreme deprivation may not generalize; longer or different interventions (improving sleep quality) could produce different effects
